Eswara Iyer, ( 1980) 4 SCC 680 did away with oral hearing of review petitions in open court and upheld the amendment made to Order 40 Rule 3 of the Supreme Court Rules, 1966 which prescribed disposal of review petitions by circulation. The said judgment is binding on the present Bench. The Constitution Bench accepted the importance of oral hearing, but generally it took the view that the Court, when it comes to b deciding a review application, decides something very minuscule, and the amended Order 40 Rule 3 sufficiently meets the requirement of the principle of audi alteram partem. The Court clarified that deciding a review petition by "circulation" would only mean that there would not be hearing in Court but still there would be discussion at a judicial conference and the Judges would meet, deliberate and reach a collective conclusion. The Court also noted that in many other jurisdictions, there was exclusion of public hearing. The Court found c justification in enacting such a rule having regard to mounting dockets and the mindless manner of filing review petitions in most of the cases. However , there are ample observations in the said Constitution Bench judgment itself, giving enough space for justifying oral hearing in cases like the present. (Paras 12 to 16) P.N. Eswara Iy er v. Supr eme Court of India, (1980) 4 SCC 680, clarifi ed Article 21 of the Constitution has its origin in nothing less than the Magna Carta (the 39th Article) of 1215 vintage which King John of England was forced to sign by his Barons. It is a little known fact that this original charter of liberty was faulted at the very start and did not get off the ground because of a Papal Bull issued by Pope Innocent III declaring this charter to be void. Strangely , like Magna Carta, Article 21 did not get off the ground for 28 years after which, unshackled, it has become the single most important fundamental right under the Constitution of India, being described as one of a holy trinity consisting of a "golden triangle", and being one of the two articles which cannot be eclipsed during an emergency (Article 359 as amended by the Constitution 44th Amendment). (Para 18) d e The fundamental right to life among all fundamental rights , is the most precious to all human beings. Over the question whether the expression "due f process of law" should be restored in place of the words "procedure established by law" , there was a sharp difference of opinion in the Constituent Assembly, even amongst the members of the Drafting Committee. The House adopted the clause as drafted by the Drafting Committee, rejecting "due process". The result, was that Article 21 gave "a carte blanche to make and provide for the arrest of any person under any circumstances as Parliament may think fit". It took 28 years for India to remedy this situation. By the Constitution (44th Amendment) g Act, even the truncated right to property was completely deleted, and in the same year in Maneka Gandhi , (1978) 1 SCC 248 , the Supreme Court held that the "procedure established by law " cannot be arbitrary but should be just , fair and reasonable. Quite apart from Article 134 of the Constitution granting an automatic right of appeal to the Supreme Court in all death sentence cases, and apart from death sentence being granted only in the rarest of rare cases, two factors need to be noted. The first is the irreversibility of the death penalty. And the second is the fact that different judicially trained minds can arrive at conclusions which, on the same facts, can be diametrically opposed to each other. The basic principle behind returning the verdict of death sentence is that it has to be awarded in the rarest of rare cases. There may be aggravating as well as mitigating circumstances which are to be examined by the Court. At the same time, it is not possible to lay down the principles to determine as to which case would fall in the category of the rarest of rare cases, justifying the death sentence. It is not even easy to mention precisely the parameters or aggravating/mitigating circumstances which should be kept in mind while arriving at such a question. Though attempts are made by Judges in various cases to state such circumstances, they remain illustrative only. (Para 29) Sher Singh v. State of Maharashtra, (2009) 6 sec 498 : (2009) 2 sec (Cri) 1150, considered Crime and punishment are two sides of the same coin. Punishment must fit the crime. The notion of "just deserts" or a sentence proportionate to the offender's culpability was the principle which, by passage of time, became applicable to criminal jurisprudence. It is not out of place to mention that in all of recorded history, there has never been a time when crime and punishment have not been the subject of debate and difference of opinion. There are no statutory guidelines to regulate punishment. Therefore, in practice, there is much variance in the matter of sentencing. In many countries, there are laws prescribing sentencing guidelines , but there is no statutory sentencing policy in India. The Judges exercise wide discretion within the statutory limits and the scope for deciding the amount of punishment is left to the judiciary to reach decision after hearing the parties. However, what factors should be considered while sentencing are not specified under law in any great detail. A sentence is a compound of many factors, including the nature of the offence as well as the circumstances extenuating or aggravating the offence. Different judicially trained minds can apply different aggravating and mitigating circumstances to ultimately arrive at a conclusion , on considering all relevant factors that the death penalty may or may not be awarded in any given case. Therefore, when a convict who has suffered the sentence of b death files a review petition , the necessity of oral hearing in such a review petition becomes an integral part of "reasonable procedure". Thus , "reasonable procedure " would encompass oral hearing of review petitions arising out of death penalties. The statement of Justice Holmes , that the life of law is not logic , it is experience, aptly applies here. Once a death sentence is executed, that results in taking away the life of the convict. If it is found thereafter that such a sentence was not warranted, that would be of no use as the life of that person cannot be brought back. Thus, a limited oral hearing even at the review stage is mandated by Article 21 of the Constitution in all death sentence cases. (Paras 30 to 32) Bachan Singh v. State of Punjab , (1980) 2 SCC 684: 1980 SCC (Cri) 580, considered Immanuel Kant: The Metaph y sics of Morals; Oliver Wendell Holmes , Jr.: The Common Law (Boston, Little, Brown & Co. 1881), refe rred to While awarding a death sentence, in most of the cases, the Supreme Court would generally be affirming the decision on this aspect already arrived at by two courts below, namely, the trial court as well as the High Court. After such an affirmation, the scope of review of such a judgment may be very narrow . At the same time, when it is a question of life and death of a person, even a remote chance of deviating from such a decision while exercising the review jurisdiction, would justify oral hearing in a review petition. Thus, oral hearing, in death sentence cases, becomes too precious to be parted with . Review petitions are inartistically drafted. And oral submissions by a skilled advocate can bring home a point which may otherwise not be succinctly stated, given the enlarged scope of review in criminal matters. The fact that the Court's overcrowded docket would be able to manage such limited oral hearings in death sentence cases only, being roughly 60 per annum, is not a factor to which great weight need be accorded as the fundamental right to life is the paramount factor in these cases. The reason for upholding the amended Order 40 Rule 3 in the Supreme Court Rules, 1966 was basically because of severe stress of the Supreme Court workload. This matter, therefore, be placed before a Bench of three Judges by the Registry as soon as possible. (Para 42) The petitioner in WP No. 77 of 2014 was arrested on 25-12-2000 and convicted. All along, the petitioner has been in jail for about 13½ years. Since the curative petition also stands dismissed after the dismissal of review petition, all these proceedings need not be reopened at this stage. Also, time taken in court proceedings cannot be taken into account to say that there is a delay which would convert a death sentence into one for life. Equally, spending 13½ years in jail does not mean that the petitioner has undergone a sentence for life. And awarding a sentence of life imprisonment means life and not a mere 14 years in jail. It is not necessary to refer to the various sections of the CrPC and IPC. Equally, Article 20( 1) of the Constitution has no manner of application as the writ petitioner is not being subjected to a penalty greater than that which might have been inflicted under the law in force at the time of commission of the offence. State of Kerala, (2007) 8 sec 312 : (2007) 3 sec (Cri) 544, cit ed It is made clear that the law laid down in this judgment viz. the right of a limited oral hearing in review petitions where death sentence is given , shall be applicable only in pending review petitions and such petitions filed in future. It will also apply where a review petition is already dismissed but the death sentence is not executed so far. In such cases, the petitioners can apply for the reopening of their review petition within one month from the date of this judgment. However, in those cases where even a curative petition is dismissed, it would not be proper to reopen such matters. (Para 46) All the writ petitions are disposed of accordingly. (Para 4 7) Per Chelameswar, J. (dissenting) No doubt, death penalty results in deprivation of the most fundamental liberty guaranteed by the Constitution resulting in an irreversible situation. Therefore, such deprivation should be only in accordance with the law (both substantive and procedural) which is consistent with the constitutional guarantee under Articles 14 and 21 of the Constitution, etc. But, such an obligation does not extend so far as to compulsorily giving an oral hearing in every case where review is sought by a condemned convict. Barring the contingency contemplated under Article 134 of the Constitution, the makers of the Constitution did not even think it fit to provide an appeal to the Supreme Court even in cases of death penalty. In cases other than which are brought before the Supreme Court as of right under Article 134 of the Constitution , the Supreme Court 's jurisdiction is discretionary. No doubt, such disc retion is to be exercised on the basis of certain establi shed principles of law. It is a matter of record that the Supreme Court in almost every case of death penalty undertakes the examination of the correctnes s of such decision. Article 137 of the Con stitution does not confer any right in any person to seek review of any judgment of the Supreme Court. On the other hand, it only recognises the authority of the Supreme Court to review its own judgments. It is a settled position of law that the courts of limited jurisdiction don't have any inherent power of review. Though the Supreme Court is the apex constitutional court with plenary jurisdiction , the makers of the Constitution thought it fit to expressly confer such a power on the Supreme Court as they were aware that if an error creeps into the judgment of the Supreme Court, there is no way of correcting it. Therefore, perhaps they did not want to leave scope for any doubt regarding the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court to review its judgments in appropriate cases . They also authorised the Supreme Court under Article 145(l)(e) of the Constitution to make rules as to the conditions subject to which a judgment of the Supreme Court could be reviewed and also make rules regarding the procedure for such review. Both Articles 137 and 145 give the Supreme Court the authority to review its judgments subject to any law made by Parliament. (Para s 68 to 70 , 49 to 57 , 64 and 66) As observed by the Supreme Court in Eswara Iyer, (1980) 4 SCC 680, it has never been held, either in this country or elsewhere , that the rule of audi alteram partem takes within its sweep the right to make oral submissions in every case. It all depends upon the demands of justice in a given case.
